cab.content: ;HIS DOCUMBftfZ IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT).EQRET.P.218 (28).Copy No.C A B I N E T.SLAUGHTER OF ANIMALS (SCOTLAND) BILL.Memorandum by the Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries,I wish to bring before the Cabinet a question arising out of the Slaughter of Animals (Scotland) Bill, on which the Secretary of State for Scotland and myself are unable to agree.The object of the Bill is to provide for the humane slaughter of animals in Scotland,Clause 1 (2) of the Bill provides in effect that no person shall slaughter an animal in a slaughterhouse or knackerfs yard unless he is the holder of a licence issued by the Local Authority, and Clause 2 (2) provides that the licence shall only be valid in the district of the Local Authority granting it.The Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries is r responsible for questions relating to diseases of animals in Scotland. It is often necessary for my Department when exercising through its officers the powers and duties under the Diseases of Animals Acts of 1894 to 1927 to slaughter animals in a slaughterhouse or knacker1 s yard, and to employ butchers brought from other districts where the butchers in the district of the Local Authority concerned are either not available or not sufficient to carry out the slaughter quickly. It may also be necessary in carrying out slaughter under the Diseases of Animals Acts for an officer of the Ministry in an emergency to slaughter animals himself. When animals are slaughtered under the direct ion,,, of the Ministry of Agriculture humane methods are always employee!I am not, therefore, proposing anything which conflicts with the object of the Bill. It is essential that the Ministry1s power "t-o.. employ any butchers (or on occasion its own officers), to carry out the slaughter of animals on an infected, place, should remain unimpaired, but the Bill apparently restricts this power and would require any officer of the Ministry or a slaughterer brought from another district (though he may be a licensed slaughterer) specially to obtain a licence from the Local Authority in which the slaughter is to take place, This formality might take some hours and the restilting delay might be disastrous.I cannot emphasise too strongly the necessity for prompt slaughter in the case of foot and mouth disease. This disease is the most infectious known and the-whole plan of campaign is based on the necessity for immediate slaughter of affected animals so as to stop at once the production of the dangerous virus of the disease. It would be intolerable If Inspectors and butchers had to stand by doing nothing until all the formalities of securing the licence from a Local Authority had been completed. It is like having a fire brigade in front of a burning house ready to act but unable to move because they had not received the necessary authority to put out the fire IClause 4 provides that any constable and any person authorised by a Local Authority may enter any slaughterhouse or knacker's yard in the district of the Local Authority for the purpose of observing whether the provisions of the Act are complied with.One of the most important provisions in the Orders made by the Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries under the Diseases of Animals Acts is that which prohibits the entry of any person into an "infected place" unless specially authorised to do so by an Inspector of the Ministry, the object being to limit the number of persons entering an infected place so as to minimise the risk of the spread of disease. It is essential that the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries should maintain this power of control over the entry of persons into Infected places. Clause 4, however, will enable any constable (who it is understood will include in Scotland in certain cases an Inspector of the S.P.C.A.) to enter any slaughterhouse or knacker's yard, which may be declared an infected place under the Diseases of Animals Acts, and will also enable a Local Authority to authorise any other person to enter such premises, without obtaining any authority from the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries or from any of its officers. The Ministry's absolute control over an infected place would, therefore, cease to exist.This is a position which I cannot contemplate with equanimity. If the local authority can grant to any person the right to enter an infected place without the permission of the Ministry's Inspector, a vital principle will have been surrendered. Our complete control will have gone. There' will be divided responsibility. One officer will be responsible for suppressing disease and another for ensuring humane methods of slaughter under circumstances where unity of command, prompt action and the minimum movement of human beings are essential.For these reasons I-have suggested an amendment which would exempt from the operation of this Bill the slaughter of animals under the Diseases of Animals Acts and Orders of the Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries. I am also prepared to agree to the inclusion in the amendment of a provision to the effect that all animals slaughtered under the Diseases of Animals Acts in Scotland shall be killed by a mechanically-operated instrument of a pattern approved by the Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries.As long as I am responsible for diseases of animals in Scotland I must have complete control of the campaign for their suppression.W. GaMINISTRY OP AGRICULTURE AND FISHERIES. 9th July, 1928. For the purposes of this Act (a) " Slaughter-house " " knackers' yard," and" local authority," have the respective mean-ings assigned to them in the Public Health (Scotland) Act, 1897;(b) The expression " animal" means any horse,mare, gelding, pony, foal, colt, filly, stallion, ass, donkey, mule, bull, cow, bullock, heifer, calf, steer, ox, sheep, ewe, wether, ram, lamb, pig, boar, hog, sow, goat and kid;10(c) Any expenses incurred by a local authority in the exercise of their powers under this Act shall be defrayed in like manner as the expenses of the local authority are defrayed under the Public Health (Scotland) Act, 1897 : Provided 15 that in the case of a local authority owning a slaughter-house such expenses may, if such local authority so determine, be defrayed out of the funds from which such slaughter-house is maintained; 20(d) " Constable " includes any constable within the meaning of the Police (Scotland) Act, 1890, and any justice of the peace constable.8.
